Issues.Title: feat(forms): expand NgModel disabled type to work with strict template type checking
Issues.Body:
NgModel internally coerces any arbitrary value that will assigned
to the `disabled` `@Input` to a boolean. This has been done to
support the common case where developers set the disabled attribute
without a value. For example:

```html
<input type="checkbox" [(ngModel)]="value" disabled>
```

This worked in View Engine without any errors because inputs were
not strictly checked. In Ivy though, developers can opt-in into
strict template type checking where the attribute would be flagged.

This is because the `NgModel#isDisabled` property type-wise only
accepts a `boolean`. To ensure that the common pattern described
above can still be used, and to reflect the actual runtime behavior,
we should add an acceptance member that makes it work without type
checking errors.

Using a coercion member means that this is not a breaking change.

**Note**: I tried creating a test for this.. but it looks like there is no way to AOT compile a component (replicating the scenario above) with strict template checking enabled. Also see #33452

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): append `advance` instructions before `i18nExp`
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, there were no `advance` instructions generated before `i18nExp` instructions and as a result, lifecycle hooks for components used inside i18n blocks were flushed too late. This commit adds the logic to generate `advance` instructions in front of `i18nExp` ones (similar to what we have in other places like interpolations, property bindings, etc), so that the necessary lifecycle hooks are flushed before expression value is captured.

This PR resolves FW-1775.

1. "Get Started" links should point the user to a page with information regarding the creation of a new project,  such as the [Setup page](https://angular.io/guide/setup-local).
2. After that, we should provide Angular's architecture overview, something like [Architecture Overview](https://angular.io/guide/architecture) in simple terms.
4. Then, introduce the user to [Your First App](https://angular.io/start) as it is. Later ask the user to continue with the [Tour of Heroes App](https://angular.io/tutorial) tutorial to give them a real taste of developing an Angular app.

**Why these suggestions?**
* There is front-end framework war out in the world and every non-Angular developers say that documentations are hard to understand. This gives them one extra reason to move away from Angular.
* Few Front-end devs in my team informed me that they couldn't clearly get things which are required to start with Angular. They mentioned that they had to navigate a few pages to get started. When I tried a fresh start by myself, I too couldn't find things clearly, even though I have been visiting  [Angular.io](https://angular.io/) since 2017.

Above suggestions are from a few devs from my team(freshers and experienced). We will be more than happy to get further suggestions in order to improve the above starter flow even better.

for (let i = parseStyle(text); (i = parseStyleNext(text, i)) >= 0;) {

Issues.Title: feat(material/*): First pass implementation of focus indicators.
Issues.Body:
**Demo:** http://100.88.8.105:4200

**Implementation summary:**

* Focus indicators were added to all components other than chips.
  * Focus indicators only added to elements that had associated click handlers. For example: `mat-selection-list` and `mat-dialog` are focusable, but not expected to ever have click handlers. If we want focus indicators for these elements, we can add them in a follow-up PR.
  * Chips will be in a follow-up PR. Focus indicator for chips likely requires an additional element.
* The class `.mat-focus-indicator` was added to the appropriate elements within each component. Components with multiple focusable elements had `.mat-focus-indicator` added to multiple elements.
  * For almost all components (besides the ones below), the class `.mat-focus-indicator` is added to the element that has focus (the actual `document.activeElement`).  Focus indicator is rendered when element has focus.
  * For checkbox, radio, and slide toggle, the class `.mat-focus-indicator` is added to the associated `mat-ripple`. This is because the actual focused input is visually hidden and consequently does not have a bounding box to render the focus indicator on. Focus indicator is rendered when the class `.cdk-focused` is present on the parent checkbox/radio/slide toggle.
  * For option, each `.mat-option` does not actually take focus as a user arrows through the options. Focus indicator is rendered when the option is active (i.e. when the class `.mat-active` is present).
* The focus indicator itself is rendered on `.mat-focus-indicator::before`. The before pseudo-element is positioned absolutely. The `.mat-focus-indicator` element is positioned relatively.
* For most components, the focus indicator has no inset/offset. For some components, the focus indicator does have inset/offset. This decision was made on a per-component basis. All components support inset focus indicators, not all components support offset focus indicators. FWIW, I believe that any component that *needs* to support offset focus indicators *does* support offset focus indicators.
* All focus indicator CSS is decoupled from core CSS. Users must manually pull in `mat-focus-indicator` and `mat-focus-indicator-theme` mixins.
* Focus indicator is always the primary color. Some mechanism to invert the color will be added in a follow-up PR.

**Some notes:**

* What's nice about using the actual focused element as the host for the focus indicator (i.e. the host for the pseudo-element) is that SRs will also draw their focus indicators on this element. It's important that the actual focused element has an appropriate bounding box, and this feature helps to enforce that. I think this is really nice.
* No new elements were added!
* `position: relative` was added to 3 components. If this is a problem, make note. These changes can also potentially live within the focus indicator mixin.
* Focus indicator appears on mouse click, which is weird. It shows up a little more frequently when using a mouse than I'd like. This is something we'll have to address in a future PR.
* Have not tested on high contrast yet.

I'll squash/rename my commits before merging to follow naming conventions.

Issues.Title: Dialog focus restoration doesn't work on mat-menu-items
Issues.Body:
If you trigger a dialog from a `mat-menu-item`'s click handler, the focused item is the mat-menu-item itself. This gets saved in `_elementFocusedBeforeDialogWasOpened`. But that element is gone from the DOM when the dialog is closed, so focus is restored to the body.

It would be cool if the dialog could somehow keep track of the fact that it was a transient menu item that was focused, and focus ought to go back to the menu's trigger instead.

Waiting a tick before opening the dialog fixes it, because the menu itself focuses the trigger before the dialog opens, so it gets the right element ref.
